title: PewDiePie and Zedd bond over being ‘banned in China’ after bizarre copyright row
text:
PewDiePie and Zedd have made the best of a bad situation together after they both claimed they’ve been ‘banned in China’.

The YouTube star, whose videos were previously blocked in India following his battle with T-Series, took to social media to vent his frustration.

‘Just found out im banned in china. s*** f***ing sucks so hard dude,’ the 29-year-old wrote.

The star – real name Felix Kjellberg – went on to say: ‘China took copyright of Pewdiepie in 2017 without me being able to stop them anyway, guess they can’t sell any more pewdiepie wedding dresses now lol.’

Felix vented his frustrations (Picture: Twitter)

In a video on the topic, the YouTube star claimed: ‘China is like that one person on Twitter that can’t take any criticism and just blocks everyone.’

He added: ‘I’m laughing but, yeah, I’m sorry if you are in China and trying to watch my videos. That kinda sucks.’

Advertisement

Advertisement

Although he mentioned the bizarre copyright situation on Twitter, he later speculated the ban was over his recent jokes about the country, one of which saw him compare President Xi to Winnie the Pooh.

Meanwhile, Pewds had also reacted to Blizzard Taiwan throwing out a Hearthstone player for showing support for the ongoing protests in Hong Kong.

Although the gamer, Ng Wai ‘Blitzchung’ Chung, was given a year’s ban and had his prize money revoked, the cash was later returned and the ban reduced to six months.

In his recent video, he said: ‘Well boys, we did it. I’m banned from China…After I spoke about the Hong Kong protests and showed their leader being mocked for looking like Winnie the Pooh, I got banned from China. That’s right.’

Zedd isn’t too happy with the situation (Picture: Twitter)

However, it seems he’s not alone in the less than ideal situation, with The Middle hitmaker Zedd responding: ‘Welcome to the club :/.’

In his video, Felix claimed the producer was banned due to ‘liking a South Park tweet’.

Previously, a selection of PewDiePie’s videos were banned in India, following his subscriber battle with record label T-Series.

Felix’s two music videos B***h Lasagna and Congratulations, which were designed to be T-Series ‘diss tracks’, were reported to be blocked in the country.

Advertisement

Advertisement

With more than 260 million views between them, the two videos were branded ‘defamatory and disparaging’ as well as containing ‘racist, inflammatory and hateful remarks,’ according to court documents.

description: PewDiePie and Zedd bond over being 'banned in China' on YouTube and Reddit after copyright row and President Xi joke.
